# Computer Science Fundamentals

<span class="lead"> </span>

## [Python Basics](../module/recHNgXTaBpnn052p)

#### Objectives:

- Student should be able to install Python 3 on their local machine, run the interactive prompt in the terminal, and run Python files through the interpreter
- Student should be able to use a print statement
- Student should be able to use white space to denote blocks
- Student should be able to use basic types (integers, floats, strings) and interact with those types
- Student should be able to perform basic list operations
- Student should be able to use basic operators to perform mathematical calculations and interact with strings and lists
- Student should be able to create formatted strings
- Student should be able to perform basic string operations
- Student should be able to evaluate conditional expressions and use boolean operators to control flow
- Student should be able to use for and while loops and break and continue statements
- Student should be able to use list comprehensions
- Student should be able to create user-defined functions and call them
- Student should be able to create user-defined classes and interact with instances of those classes
- Student should be able to perform basic dictionary operations
- Student should be able to import modules

## [Problem Solving](../module/recagU9ihCuMePtbx)

#### Objectives:

- Student should be able to name and describe the details of each step of Lambda's Problem-Solving Framework (U.P.E.R)
- Student should be able to effectively ask for help by giving the expected vs. experienced behavior, explaining what specific actions they've taken so far, and providing all relevant information and code

## [Time and Space Complexity](../module/recZ6g2C5xkxHmT16)

#### Objectives:

- Student should be able to recognize mutable and immutable objects
- Student should be able to compare the time complexity of different approaches to a problem using Big O notation
- Student should be able to compare the space complexity of different approaches to a problem using Big O notation

## [Computer Memory Basics](../module/recy2QANAS6Blpc5o)

#### Objectives:

- Student should be able to understand random access memory (RAM) as it relates to data structures
- Student should be able to convert back and forth from decimal to binary
- Student should be able to understand how fixed-width integers are stored in memory
- Student should be able to describe, in general terms, how arrays are stored in memory and the time complexity of lookups
- Student should be able to describe character encoding and how strings are stored in memory
